candy. Mrs. Lily is the one who brought the traditional Dragon Beard candy
to Singapore in 1988.
She passed on the craft to her nephew,
Roger, to make Dragon Beard candy.
Roger cooked the malt until it became
thick, then pulled the malt mass into
thousands of threads as strong as silk. Finally,
he wrapped the malt fibers.  This candy is
filled with crushed peanuts and when eaten,
this candy melts quickly in the mouth. Roger also
added a special ingredient that makes the
eater exhale a white smoke
like a dragon exhaling smoke, so
his candy is called by many Singaporeans.
is dragon breath candy. Roger said

in the world, the Sunda Islands of
Indonesia are where they are located.  We can
encounter this legendary animal, even
though it doesn't
fly or breathe fire like in the movies,
it will likely become
a legend if not properly preserved. The
Comodo dragon is a large dragon.
In the world today, an
adult is up to 3 m long and weighs 70 kg.
They can knock down their prey with a
strong blow using their sharp, venomous teeth.
In the past, kodo dragons were often hunted to
sell to gardens.  collectors
or for their skin and legs. Until 1980,
Indonesia established the Komodo National Park,
keeping the number of this animal
at a relatively stable level of about 3,000 animals
because it only resides on a few
Indonesian islands.  With limited genetic diversity,
Komodo dragons are very sensitive to
climate change. High populations of Sea Germans
can sweep the low hills near the coast, and
frequent changes in rain will cause
Komodo dragons to gradually lose their egg-laying and breeding habitats.  In
July 2019, the government of East
Nengara closed the famous tourist island
Comodo for 2 months to protect the
mating and hatching process of
